Optimal Gradient Compression
for Distributed and Federated Learning

  Alyazeed Albasyoni   Mher Safaryan   Laurent Condat   Peter Richtárik
XXX
King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST)
(September 28, 2020)
Abstract

Communicating information, like gradient vectors, between computing nodes in distributed and federated learning is typically an unavoidable burden, resulting in scalability issues. Indeed, communication might be slow and costly. Recent advances in communication-efficient training algorithms have reduced this bottleneck by using compression techniques, in the form of sparsification, quantization, or low-rank approximation. Since compression is a lossy, or inexact, process, the iteration complexity is typically worsened; but the total communication complexity can improve significantly, possibly leading to large computation time savings. In this paper, we investigate the fundamental trade-off between the number of bits needed to encode compressed vectors and the compression error. We perform both worst-case and average-case analysis, providing tight lower bounds. In the worst-case analysis, we introduce an efficient compression operator, Sparse Dithering, which is very close to the lower bound. In the average-case analysis, we design a simple compression operator, Spherical Compression, which naturally achieves the lower bound. Thus, our new compression schemes significantly outperform the state of the art. We conduct numerical experiments to illustrate this improvement.

1 Introduction

Due to the necessity of huge amounts of data to achieve high-quality machine learning models [27, 35], modern large-scale training procedures are executed in a distributed environment [5, 36]. In such a setup, both storage and computation needs are reduced, as the overall data (potentially too big to fit into a single machine) is partitioned among the nodes and computation is carried out in parallel. However, in order to keep the consensus across the network, compute nodes have to exchange some information about their local progress [31, 17, 4]. The demand of information communication between all machines in a distributed setup is typically a burden, resulting in a scalability issue commonly referred to as communication bottleneck [28, 40, 23]. To reduce the amount of information to be transferred, information is passed in a compressed or inexact form. Information lossy compression is a common practice, where original information is encoded approximately with essentially fewer bits, while introducing additional controllable distortion into the decoded message.

In the context of Federated Learning [21, 24, 15], communication between devices arises naturally, as data is initially decentralized and should remain so, for privacy purposes. Actually, it might be desirable for each unit, or client, to compress/encode/encrypt the information they are going to share, in order to minimize private data disclosures. Another practical scenario where compression methods are useful is when storage capabilities are scarce or there is no need to save complete versions of the data. In such cases, the representation of the data (encoding and decoding schemes) can be optimized and with little or no precision loss, one can allocate significantly less memory space.

1.1 Related Work

Recently, substantial amount of work has been devoted to the advances of communication-efficient training algorithms by utilizing various types of compression mechanisms, such as sparsification [38, 37, 10], quantization [1, 39, 13] and low-rank approximation [36]. Typically, the information communicated by computing nodes consists of local gradients, to which compression operators are applied. For example, one popular example of such compression operator is Top-k𝑘k [3], which transfers only k𝑘k coordinates of the gradient with largest magnitudes.

The theoretical foundation of lossy compression has long history and is based on Rate-Distortion Theory introduced by Shannon in his seminal papers [29, 30]. Recently, rate-distortion theory has been utilized in the context of model compression [12, 8]. In contrast to this, another line of research is devoted to the lossless compression methods which is rooted in Shannon’s source coding theorem [9]. Both approaches exploit statistical properties of the input messages for analyses, which differs from our setting.

We investigate the problem of lossy compression, namely encoding vectors x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} without prior knowledge on the distribution, for any d≥1𝑑1d\geq 1, into as few bits as possible, while introducing as little distortion as possible. Formally, we measure the distortion of a (possibly randomized) compression operator 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} by its constant α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1] such that 𝔼​[‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2]≤α​‖x‖2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2𝛼superscriptnorm𝑥2\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}\right]\leq\alpha\|x\|^{2} for every x𝑥x, where the norm is the Euclidean norm (see Definitions 1, 2 and 3 for details). We denote by b𝑏b the number of bits (in the worst case or in expectation) needed to encode 𝒞​(x)𝒞𝑥\mathcal{C}(x). Intuitively, b𝑏b and α𝛼\alpha cannot be too small at the same time: they are antagonistic and ruled by a fundamental rate-distortion trade-off. As a matter of fact, as shown in [26], the following lower bound, referred to as uncertainty principle for communication compression, holds (if omitted, the base of log\log is assumed to be 222):

α​ 4b/d≥1or, equivalently,b≥d​12​log⁡1α.formulae-sequence𝛼superscript4𝑏𝑑1or, equivalently,𝑏𝑑121𝛼\alpha\,4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1\quad\text{or, equivalently,}\quad b\geq d\,\frac{1}{2}\log\frac{1}{\alpha}. (1)

In this work, we investigate this trade-off more deeply. We perform two types of analyses: worst case analysis (WCA) and average case analysis (ACA). Then, capitalizing on this new knowledge, we design new efficient compression schemes. Note that our derivations deal with real numbers, compressed using a finite number of bits. We should keep in mind that numbers are represented by finite-precision, say 32 bits, floats in computers. We can safely omit this aspect in the derivations; we discuss this point in more details in the Appendix.

1.2 Contributions

Here we summarize our key contributions.

∙∙\bullet (WCA) Tighter bounds on minimal communication. First, we construct a compression scheme with α𝛼\alpha distortion and b𝑏b encoding bits (in the worst case), which satisfies

α​ 4b/d≤poly​(d)1/dorb≤d​12​log⁡1α+𝒪​(log⁡d).formulae-sequence𝛼superscript4𝑏𝑑polysuperscript𝑑1𝑑or𝑏𝑑121𝛼𝒪𝑑\alpha\,4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\leq\text{\rm poly}(d)^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{d}}}\quad\text{or}\quad b\leq d\,\frac{1}{2}\log\frac{1}{\alpha}+{\cal O}(\log{d}). (2)

This implies the asymptotic tightness of the bound (1) as the dimension d𝑑d grows (see Theorem 2). Then, we investigate the minimal number of bits (in the worst case) b∗​(α,d)superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑b^{*}(\alpha,d) as a function of distortion α𝛼\alpha and dimension d𝑑d proving that

b∗​(α,d)=−log⁡P​(α,d)+log⁡d+12​log⁡log⁡d+e,superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑𝑃𝛼𝑑𝑑12𝑑𝑒b^{*}(\alpha,d)=-\log P(\alpha,d)+\log d+\frac{1}{2}\log\log d+e,

where P​(α,d)≔12​Iα​(d−12,12)≔𝑃𝛼𝑑12subscript𝐼𝛼𝑑1212P(\alpha,d)\coloneqq\frac{1}{2}I_{\alpha}(\frac{d-1}{2},\frac{1}{2}) with Iαsubscript𝐼𝛼I_{\alpha} being the regularized incomplete beta function, and e𝑒e is negligible additive error with |e|≤12​log⁡log⁡d+𝒪​(1)𝑒12𝑑𝒪1|e|\leq\frac{1}{2}\log\log d+{\cal O}(1) (see Theorem 5), as opposed to 𝒪​(log⁡d)𝒪𝑑{\cal O}(\log{d}) in (1) and (2).

∙∙\bullet (WCA) Near optimal and practical compressor. Motivated by these lower bounds we turn to the construction of a compression method which would be optimal and implementable in high dimensions. The example compression schemes in Theorem 2 ensuring (2) or in Theorem 5 are optimal but impractical, due to the exponential computation time to compress a vector. To make the scheme efficient, we slightly depart from the optimal boundary and propose a new efficient compression method—Sparse Dithering (SD). Both deterministic (biased) and randomized (unbiased) versions of SD are analyzed, and comparisons with existing methods are made, showing that we outperform the state of the art. In the special case, the encoding of deterministic SD with α=1/10𝛼110\alpha=\nicefrac{{1}}{{10}} distortion requires at most 30+log⁡d+3.35​d30𝑑3.35𝑑30+\log d+3.35d bits, which is optimal within 1.69​d1.69𝑑1.69d additional bits (see Theorem 3).

∙∙\bullet (ACA) Lower bound on average communication. Switching to the average case analysis, we establish a lower bound −log⁡P​(α,d)≤B𝑃𝛼𝑑𝐵-\log P(\alpha,d)\leq B on the expected number of bits B𝐵B needed to encode a compression operator from ℂ​(α)ℂ𝛼\mathbb{C}(\alpha) (see Definition 3).

∙∙\bullet (ACA) Compressor with optimal average communication. As an attempt to reach the lower bound obtained in the average case analysis, we first analyze the randomized (and unbiased) version of SD. We prove that with variance ω>0𝜔0\omega>0 it requires at most

30+log⁡d+(log⁡3+12​ω)​d30𝑑312𝜔𝑑30+\log d+\left(\log 3+\frac{1}{2\sqrt{\omega}}\right)d

bits in expectation (see Theorem 7). In the special case of ω=1/4𝜔14\omega=\nicefrac{{1}}{{4}}, it provides ≈9.9×\approx 9.9\times bandwidth savings. However, this scheme is suboptimal with respect to the lower bound. We finally present a simple compression operator–Spherical Compression–which attains the lower bound with less than 333 extra bits, namely it communicates B<−log⁡P​(α,d)+3𝐵𝑃𝛼𝑑3B<-\log P(\alpha,d)+3 bits in expectation (see Theorem 8).

2 Classes of Compression Operators

Here we formally define and perform preliminary analysis for three general classes of compression operators, that will be considered throughout the paper. We start with the most common and well studied class of unbiased compressors [2, 39, 18, 38].

Definition 1 (ω𝜔\omega-compressors).

We denote by 𝕌​(ω)𝕌𝜔\mathbb{U}(\omega) the class of unbiased compression operators 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} with variance ω≥0𝜔0\omega\geq 0; that is, 𝔼​[𝒞​(x)]=x𝔼delimited-[]𝒞𝑥𝑥\mathbb{E}\left[\mathcal{C}(x)\right]=x and

𝔼​[‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2]≤ω​‖x‖2,∀x∈ℝd.formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2𝜔superscriptnorm𝑥2for-all𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}\right]\leq\omega\|x\|^{2},\ \ \forall x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (3)

Another broad class of compressions operators, for which compressed learning algorithms have been successfully analysed [16, 32, 42, 6], is the class of biased operators, which are contractive in expectation.

Definition 2 (α𝛼\alpha-contractive operators).

We denote by 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) the class of (possibly biased and randomized) compression operators 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} with α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1]-contractive property; that is,

𝔼​[‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2]≤α​‖x‖2,∀x∈ℝd.formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2𝛼superscriptnorm𝑥2for-all𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}\right]\leq\alpha\|x\|^{2},\qquad\forall x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (4)

Analogous to parameter ω𝜔\omega for the variance, the parameter α𝛼\alpha is referred to as normalized variance or distortion threshold111note that the definition of distortion in rate–distortion theory is slightly different than what we define.. It has been shown, that the class 𝕌​(ω)𝕌𝜔\mathbb{U}(\omega) can be embedded into 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha). Specifically, if 𝒞∈𝕌​(ω)𝒞𝕌𝜔{\cal C}\in\mathbb{U}(\omega) then 1ω+1​𝒞∈𝔹​(ωω+1)1𝜔1𝒞𝔹𝜔𝜔1\frac{1}{\omega+1}{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}(\frac{\omega}{\omega+1}) (see e.g. Lemma 1 in [26]). We will also consider the subclass of strictly contractive operators which, compared to operators from 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha), are contractive for all realizations rather than in expectation:

Definition 3 (Strictly α𝛼\alpha-contractive operators).

We denote by ℂ​(α)ℂ𝛼\mathbb{C}(\alpha) the class of (possibly biased and randomized) compression operators 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} with α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1]-strictly contractive property; that is,

‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2≤α​‖x‖2,∀x∈ℝd.formulae-sequencesuperscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2𝛼superscriptnorm𝑥2for-all𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}\leq\alpha\|x\|^{2},\qquad\forall x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (5)

2.1 Compression operator as composition of encoder and decoder

Generally speaking, compression is a two-sided notion, in the sense that one end encodes the message, while the other end decodes it to estimate the original information. An encoder is any mapping E:ℝd→{0,1}∗:𝐸→superscriptℝ𝑑superscript01E\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\{0,1\}^{*} which maps a given vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} to some finite word from the set of all finite words {0,1}∗superscript01\{0,1\}^{*} with the binary alphabet {0,1}01\{0,1\}. A decoder, on the other hand, is a mapping D:{0,1}∗→ℝd:𝐷→superscript01superscriptℝ𝑑D\colon\{0,1\}^{*}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} which aims to reconstruct the initial vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} from the finite binary codeword E​(x)𝐸𝑥E(x). Thus, a compression operator 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} can be decomposed into an encoder and decoder so that 𝒞​(x)=D​(E​(x))𝒞𝑥𝐷𝐸𝑥{\cal C}(x)=D(E(x)). The number of bits needed to transfer a compressed version of x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is the length |E​(x)|𝐸𝑥|E(x)| of the binary word E​(x)𝐸𝑥E(x). In the worst case analysis we are interested in the length of the longest codeword supx,𝒞​(x)|E​(x)|subscriptsupremum𝑥𝒞𝑥𝐸𝑥\sup_{x,{\cal C}(x)}|E(x)|, while in average case analysis we investigate the size of the longest expected codeword supx𝔼𝒞​[|E​(x)|]subscriptsupremum𝑥subscript𝔼𝒞delimited-[]𝐸𝑥\sup_{x}\mathbb{E}_{{\cal C}}\left[|E(x)|\right].

Notice that a compression operator from any of the three classes requires countably many bits in order to encode points near x=0𝑥0x=0 and x=∞𝑥x=\infty. We address this issue in the Appendix by considering relaxed classes of compression operators capturing finite representation of a single float in machines. From now on, we exclude trivial cases ω=0,α∈{0,1}formulae-sequence𝜔0𝛼01\omega=0,\;\alpha\in\{0,1\} and assume ω>0,α∈(0,1)formulae-sequence𝜔0𝛼01\omega>0,\;\alpha\in(0,1).

2.2 Two senses of optimality for compression

It is worth distinguishing between optimality within a class in a single step of communication and optimality of total communication throughout the optimization process leading to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accuracy, e.g. ‖xt−x⋆‖2‖x0−x⋆‖2≤ϵsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑡superscript𝑥⋆2superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥0superscript𝑥⋆2italic-ϵ\frac{\|x^{t}-x^{\star}\|^{2}}{\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\|^{2}}\leq\epsilon for a prescribed ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, where t𝑡t is the iteration counter. Our theoretical contributions mainly deal with the first sense of optimality. Regarding the second view of optimality, the following proposition shows that Compressed Gradient Descent (CGD) can converge at significantly different speeds for different operators from 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha).

Proposition 1.

If 𝒞∈𝔹​(α)𝒞𝔹𝛼\mathcal{C}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha), the iteration complexity of CGD is 11−α11𝛼\frac{1}{1-\alpha} times bigger than for GD; that is CGD needs 11−α11𝛼\frac{1}{1-\alpha} times more iterations than GD to obtain the same ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accuracy. Moreover, if 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is additionally unbiased, then only 1+α1𝛼1+\alpha times more iterations are sufficient.

Thus, if we aim to minimize the total communication complexity ensuring convergence to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accuracy, then the optimal operator 𝒞∗superscript𝒞{\cal C}^{*} should be either unbiased, or it will need to satisfy not only the direct condition, 𝔼​[|E𝒞∗​(x)|]≤𝔼​[|E𝒞​(x)|]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐸superscript𝒞𝑥𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐸𝒞𝑥\mathbb{E}[|E_{{\cal C}^{*}}(x)|]\leq\mathbb{E}[|E_{{\cal C}}(x)|] for all operators 𝒞∈𝔹​(α)𝒞𝔹𝛼{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha), but also the additional condition 𝔼​[|E𝒞∗​(x)|]≤(1−α2)​𝔼​[|E𝒰​(x)|]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐸superscript𝒞𝑥1superscript𝛼2𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐸𝒰𝑥\mathbb{E}[|E_{{\cal C}^{*}}(x)|]\leq(1-\alpha^{2})\mathbb{E}[|E_{\mathcal{U}}(x)|] for all unbiased operators 𝒰∈𝔹​(α)𝒰𝔹𝛼\mathcal{U}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha). It is important to see that when α𝛼\alpha is close to 111, then this additional constraint is hard to satisfy when 𝒞∗superscript𝒞\mathcal{C}^{*} is not unbiased. For α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, we show that this is indeed the case by obtaining an optimal biased operator 𝒞∗∈𝔹​(α)superscript𝒞𝔹𝛼\mathcal{C}^{*}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha), which we call Spherical Compression, and another unbiased one, which we call Sparse Dithering. We show that the latter is more suitable in practice due to its unbiasedness, and hence, convergence occurs in much fewer iterations, and that this is most pronounced when α𝛼\alpha is close to 1. In addition to being computationally efficient, we show that Sparse Dithering can guarantee reducing the total training communication by ≈9.9×\approx 9.9\times compared to full precision gradient communication of 323232-bits floats.

2.3 Dimension-tolerant compression schemes.

By dimension-tolerant compression, we mean a collection of operators 𝒞¯=(𝒞d)d≥d0¯𝒞subscriptsubscript𝒞𝑑𝑑subscript𝑑0\bar{{\cal C}}=\left({\cal C}_{d}\right)_{d\geq d_{0}} that can be used to compress vectors x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for any d≥d0𝑑subscript𝑑0d\geq d_{0} and there exists a non-trivial fixed upper bound (ω¯<∞¯𝜔\bar{\omega}<\infty or α¯<1¯𝛼1\bar{\alpha}<1) for variances (ωdsubscript𝜔𝑑\omega_{d} or αdsubscript𝛼𝑑\alpha_{d}), i.e. ωd≤ω¯<∞subscript𝜔𝑑¯𝜔\omega_{d}\leq\bar{\omega}<\infty or αd≤α¯<1subscript𝛼𝑑¯𝛼1\alpha_{d}\leq\bar{\alpha}<1 for any d≥d0𝑑subscript𝑑0d\geq d_{0}.

Below we show that for such collection of compression schemes, it is necessary and sufficient to use at least a constant amount of bits per dimension on average and this constant can be arbitrarily small.

Theorem 1.

The following holds:

  • (i)

    If 𝒞¯=(𝒞d)d≥d0¯𝒞subscriptsubscript𝒞𝑑𝑑subscript𝑑0\bar{{\cal C}}=\left({\cal C}_{d}\right)_{d\geq d_{0}} is a dimension-tolerant compression composed of operators from 𝕌​(ω)𝕌𝜔\mathbb{U}(\omega) (𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) or ℂ​(α)ℂ𝛼\mathbb{C}(\alpha)), then there exists a positive constant c>0𝑐0c>0 (independent of d𝑑d) such that for any d≥d0𝑑subscript𝑑0d\geq d_{0} at least c​d𝑐𝑑cd bits are required in the worst case to encode 𝒞d​(x)∈ℝdsubscript𝒞𝑑𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}_{d}(x)\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for any x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

  • (ii)

    Let c>0𝑐0c>0 be a fixed positive constant. Then there exists a dimension-tolerant compression 𝒞¯=(𝒞d)d≥3¯𝒞subscriptsubscript𝒞𝑑𝑑3\bar{{\cal C}}=\left({\cal C}_{d}\right)_{d\geq 3} composed of operators from 𝕌​(ω)𝕌𝜔\mathbb{U}(\omega) with ω=𝒪​(1/c)𝜔𝒪1𝑐\omega={\cal O}(\nicefrac{{1}}{{c}}) (𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) or ℂ​(α)ℂ𝛼\mathbb{C}(\alpha) with α=11+Ω​(c)𝛼11Ω𝑐\alpha=\frac{1}{1+\Omega(c)}) such that 𝒞d​(x)∈ℝdsubscript𝒞𝑑𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}_{d}(x)\in\mathbb{R}^{d} can be encoded with c​d𝑐𝑑cd bits for any x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Thus, Θ​(d)Θ𝑑\Theta(d) bits need to be transmitted in order to bound the variance by a constant. The same asymptotic bound, Θ​(d)Θ𝑑\Theta(d) bits per node, on total communication holds for distributed mean estimation [41, 20, 33].

2.4 Compressed learning algorithms

To highlight the importance of investigating the communication-variance trade-off of compression operators, we present how these operators affect the performance of compressed learning algorithms. For the sake of simplicity, consider distributed Compressed Gradient Descent (CGD) with compression operator 𝒞∈𝕌​(ω)𝒞𝕌𝜔{\cal C}\in\mathbb{U}(\omega) solving the following smooth non-convex optimization problem

minx∈ℝd⁡f​(x)≔1n​∑i=1nfi​(x),≔subscript𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝑥1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x),

where n𝑛n is the number of nodes or machines available and fi​(x)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥f_{i}(x) is the loss function corresponding to the data stored at node i𝑖i. Hence, CGD algorithm iteratively performs the updates xt+1=xt−γt​gtsuperscript𝑥𝑡1superscript𝑥𝑡subscript𝛾𝑡superscript𝑔𝑡x^{t+1}=x^{t}-\gamma_{t}g^{t} with unbiased gradient estimator

where L>0𝐿0L>0 is the smoothness parameter. Now, the term that is affected by compression and slowing down the convergence is the last one, namely the variance of estimator gtsuperscript𝑔𝑡g^{t}, which can be transform into

Clearly, in case of no compression (ω=0𝜔0\omega=0), this term vanishes. Thus, the slowdown caused by the compression operator 𝒞∈𝕌​(ω)𝒞𝕌𝜔{\cal C}\in\mathbb{U}(\omega) is controlled by its parameter ω𝜔\omega.

Similarly, for compression operators from 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) or ℂ​(α)ℂ𝛼\mathbb{C}(\alpha), the parameter α𝛼\alpha controls the slowdown. Table 1 summarizes iteration complexities of various learning algorithms exploiting compressed communication and exposes the dependence of the variance (ω𝜔\omega and α𝛼\alpha) of compression operator. The conclusion from this discussion and from Table 1 is that to facilitate fast and communication-efficient training process, one needs to design compression operators minimizing both variance and number of encoding bits. This is the motivation of our work. Therefore, compression operators developed in this paper can be incorporated in any compressed learning algorithm, including all the ones in Table 1.

3 Worst-Case Analysis

We start our analysis of compression operators with respect to the number of encoding bits in the worst case. First, we show that the lower bound (1) for the class 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) is asymptotically tight for any α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1). Then, we design an efficient compression operator from ℂ​(α)ℂ𝛼\mathbb{C}(\alpha), Sparse Dithering, which is within a small constant factor of being optimal. Finally, we derive asymptotically tighter lower and upper bounds.

3.1 Asymptotic tightness of the lower bound (1)

First, we show that for any fixed α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1), the constant 1 in the lower bound (1) is not improvable. We denote by 𝕊d={x∈ℝd:‖x‖=1}superscript𝕊𝑑conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑norm𝑥1\mathbb{S}^{d}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\ :\ \|x\|=1\} the unit sphere of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Theorem 2.

For any given α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1) and d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3 there exists an α𝛼\alpha-contractive compression operator 𝒞:𝕊d→ℝd:𝒞→superscript𝕊𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{S}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}, such that

α​ 4b/d≤(1600​d2​log⁡d)2/d,𝛼superscript4𝑏𝑑superscript1600superscript𝑑2𝑑2𝑑\alpha\,4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\leq\left(1600d^{2}\log d\right)^{\nicefrac{{2}}{{d}}}, (6)

where b𝑏b is the number of bits (in the worst case) needed to encode 𝒞​(x)∈ℝd𝒞𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}(x)\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for any unit vector x∈𝕊d𝑥superscript𝕊𝑑x\in\mathbb{S}^{d}. In particular, for any α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1) and ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 one can choose d𝑑d large enough such that compression operator 𝒞𝒞{\cal C} satisfies

α​ 4b/d<1+ϵ.𝛼superscript4𝑏𝑑1italic-ϵ\alpha\,4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}<1+\epsilon. (7)
Remark 1.

Using covering results from [11] (see Theorem 1), the constant 1600 in (6) can be reduced up to 2. Using tighter inequalities for the ΓΓ\Gamma function, the term d2superscript𝑑2d^{2} can be improved as well. However, these will not improve the inequality (7). Notice that the right hand side of (6) approaches 1 quickly; for d=103𝑑superscript103d=10^{3} it is ≈1.047absent1.047\approx 1.047.

Note that the compression operator in this theorem acts on 𝕊dsuperscript𝕊𝑑\mathbb{S}^{d}, not ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. However, allocating an additional constant amount of bits for the norm ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\| (say 313131 bits in float32 format), we can extend the domain of compression operators without hurting the asymptotic tightness. Thus, the lower bound (1) is asymptotically tight for the class 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha).

Although the construction of this theorem yields an optimal contractive operator, it is infeasible to apply in high dimensions.

3.2 New Compressor: Sparse Dithering (SD)

With the aim of constructing both optimal and efficient compression operators, we introduce a new compression scheme–Sparse Dithering (SD)–which is efficient in high dimension and nearly optimal. In some sense, SD can viewed as an effective combination of Top-k𝑘k sparsification [3] and random dithering with uniform levels [2]. The essential novelty is the encoding scheme and better upper bound on the number of communicated bits. In this section, we present a deterministic and hence biased version of SD.

Construction and variance bound. To compress a given nonzero vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we first compress the normalized vector u=x/‖x‖∈𝕊d𝑢𝑥norm𝑥superscript𝕊𝑑u=x/\|x\|\in\mathbb{S}^{d} and then rescale it. To quantize the coordinates of the unit vector u𝑢u, we apply dithering with levels 2​ki​h,ki≥02subscript𝑘𝑖ℎsubscript𝑘𝑖02k_{i}h,\;k_{i}\geq 0, where h=ν/dℎ𝜈𝑑h=\sqrt{\nu/d} is the half-step and ν>0𝜈0\nu>0 is a free parameter. For each coordinate ui,i∈[d]subscript𝑢𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑑u_{i},i\in[d] we choose the nearest level so that ||ui|−2​ki​h|≤hsubscript𝑢𝑖2subscript𝑘𝑖ℎℎ||u_{i}|-2k_{i}h|\leq h. Letting u^i=sign(ui)⁡ 2​ki​hsubscript^𝑢𝑖signsubscript𝑢𝑖2subscript𝑘𝑖ℎ\hat{u}_{i}=\operatorname*{{\rm sign}}(u_{i})\,2k_{i}h we have |ui−u^i|≤hsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript^𝑢𝑖ℎ|u_{i}-\hat{u}_{i}|\leq h for all i∈[d]𝑖delimited-[]𝑑i\in[d]. Therefore,

‖u−u^‖2=∑i=1d(ui−u^i)2≤d​h2=ν.superscriptnorm𝑢^𝑢2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript^𝑢𝑖2𝑑superscriptℎ2𝜈\|u-\hat{u}\|^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{d}(u_{i}-\hat{u}_{i})^{2}\leq dh^{2}=\nu.

Note that, after applying the scaling factor ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\|, this gives a compression with variance at most ν𝜈\nu. However, ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\| is not always the best option. Specifically, we can choose the scaling factor γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 so to minimize the variance ‖x−γ​u^‖2superscriptnorm𝑥𝛾^𝑢2\|x-\gamma\hat{u}\|^{2}, which yields the optimal factor γ∗=⟨x,u^⟩‖u^‖2superscript𝛾𝑥^𝑢superscriptnorm^𝑢2\gamma^{*}=\frac{\left\langle x,\hat{u}\right\rangle}{\|\hat{u}\|^{2}} with the optimal variance of ‖x−γ∗​u^‖2=sin2⁡φ​‖x‖2superscriptnorm𝑥superscript𝛾^𝑢2superscript2𝜑superscriptnorm𝑥2\|x-\gamma^{*}\hat{u}\|^{2}=\sin^{2}\varphi\,\|x\|^{2}, where φ∈[0,π/2]𝜑0𝜋2\varphi\in[0,\nicefrac{{\pi}}{{2}}] is the angle222in case of 𝒞​(x)=0𝒞𝑥0{\cal C}(x)=0 we let φ=π/2𝜑𝜋2\varphi=\nicefrac{{\pi}}{{2}}. between x𝑥x and u^^𝑢\hat{u}. Hence, defining the compression operator as 𝒞​(x)=γ∗​u^𝒞𝑥superscript𝛾^𝑢{\cal C}(x)=\gamma^{*}\hat{u}, we have the following bound on the variance:

‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2≤min⁡(ν,sin2⁡φ)​‖x‖2.superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2𝜈superscript2𝜑superscriptnorm𝑥2\|{\cal C}(x)-x\|^{2}\leq\min\left(\nu,\sin^{2}\varphi\right)\|x\|^{2}.

Encoding scheme. We now describe the corresponding encoding scheme into a sequence of bits. With the following notations:

γ≔2​h​γ∗∈ℝ+,k≔(ki)i=1d∈ℕ+d,s≔(sign(ui​ki))i=1d∈{−1,0,1}d,formulae-sequence≔𝛾2ℎsuperscript𝛾subscriptℝ≔𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝑖1𝑑superscriptsubscriptℕ𝑑≔𝑠superscriptsubscriptsignsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖𝑖1𝑑superscript101𝑑\gamma\coloneqq 2h\gamma^{*}\in\mathbb{R}_{+},\quad k\coloneqq(k_{i})_{i=1}^{d}\in\mathbb{N}_{+}^{d},\quad s\coloneqq\left(\operatorname*{{\rm sign}}(u_{i}k_{i})\right)_{i=1}^{d}\in\{-1,0,1\}^{d},

the compression operator can be written as 𝒞​(x)=γ∗​u^=2​h​γ∗​sign(u)⁡k=γ​s​k𝒞𝑥superscript𝛾^𝑢2ℎsuperscript𝛾sign𝑢𝑘𝛾𝑠𝑘{\cal C}(x)=\gamma^{*}\hat{u}=2h\gamma^{*}\,\operatorname*{{\rm sign}}(u)\,k=\gamma\,s\,k. So, we need to encode the triple (γ,s,k)𝛾𝑠𝑘(\gamma,s,k). As γ∈ℝ+𝛾subscriptℝ\gamma\in\mathbb{R}_{+}, we need only 313131 bits for the scaling factor. Next we encode s𝑠s. Let

n0≔|{i∈[d]:si=0}|=|{i∈[d]:ki=0}|≔subscript𝑛0conditional-set𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscript𝑠𝑖0conditional-set𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscript𝑘𝑖0n_{0}\coloneqq|\{i\in[d]\colon s_{i}=0\}|=|\{i\in[d]\colon k_{i}=0\}|

be the number of coordinates uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} that are compressed to 0. To communicate s𝑠s, we first send the locations of those n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} coordinates and then d−n0𝑑subscript𝑛0d-n_{0} bits for the values ±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1. Sending n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} positions can be done by sending log⁡d𝑑\log d bits representing the number n0subscript𝑛0n_{0}, afterwards sending log⁡(dn0)binomial𝑑subscript𝑛0\log\binom{d}{n_{0}} bits for the positions. We encode ki≥1subscript𝑘𝑖1k_{i}\geq 1 with kisubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i} bits: ki−1subscript𝑘𝑖1k_{i}-1 ones followed by a zero. Hence, encoding k𝑘k requires ∑kisubscript𝑘𝑖\sum k_{i} bits.

A theoretical upper bound on the total number of bits for any choice of parameter ν>0𝜈0\nu>0 is given in the Appendix. Below, we highlight one special case of ν=1/10𝜈110\nu=\nicefrac{{1}}{{10}}.

Theorem 3.

Deterministic SD compression operator with parameter ν=1/10𝜈110\nu=\nicefrac{{1}}{{10}} belongs to ℂ​(1/10)ℂ110\mathbb{C}(\nicefrac{{1}}{{10}}) communicating 30+log⁡d+3.35​d30𝑑3.35𝑑30+\log d+3.35d bits at most. In addition, ignoring 30+log⁡d30𝑑30+\log d negligible bits, SD is within a factor of

of optimality; that is, at most 1.69​d1.69𝑑1.69d more bits are sent in comparison to optimal compression with the same normalized variance 1/10110\nicefrac{{1}}{{10}}.

3.3 Tighter bounds on minimal communication

We first look into the tightness of (1) when the normalized variance α𝛼\alpha approaches 111. In particular, for α=1−1d𝛼11𝑑\alpha=1-\frac{1}{d} the lower bound (1) implies that the number of bits b𝑏b is lower bounded by some constant. However, the following holds:

Theorem 4.

For any compression operator from 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha), with α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1), at least log⁡d𝑑\log{d} bits are needed.

As briefly mentioned before, the lower bound (1) is tight up to a 𝒪​(log⁡d)𝒪𝑑{\cal O}(\log d) additive error term. Here we perform a deeper analysis of the same lower bound.

Definition 4.

For a fixed α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1) and dimension d𝑑d, consider compression operators 𝒞∈𝔹​(α)𝒞𝔹𝛼{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha) with underlying encoder E𝐸E, decoder D𝐷D and define b∗​(α,d)superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑b^{*}(\alpha,d) as the minimum number of bits in the worst case:

b∗​(α,d)=min𝒞∈𝔹​(α)⁡max‖x‖=1⁡|E​(x)|.superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑subscript𝒞𝔹𝛼subscriptnorm𝑥1𝐸𝑥b^{*}(\alpha,d)=\min_{{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha)}\max_{\|x\|=1}|E(x)|.

In other words, for any compression operator from 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) there exists a unit vector that cannot be encoded into less than b∗​(α,d)superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑b^{*}(\alpha,d) bits and it shows the least amount of bits with such property.

Combining lower bound (1) with (6) of Theorem 2, yields

b∗​(α,d)=12​log⁡1α+e​ with error term ​ 0≤e=𝒪​(log⁡d).superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑121𝛼𝑒 with error term  0𝑒𝒪𝑑b^{*}(\alpha,d)=\frac{1}{2}\log\frac{1}{\alpha}+e\;\text{ with error term }\;0\leq e={\cal O}(\log d).

Denoting P​(α,d)≔12​Iα​(d−12,12)∈(0,12)≔𝑃𝛼𝑑12subscript𝐼𝛼𝑑1212012P(\alpha,d)\coloneqq\frac{1}{2}I_{\alpha}\left(\frac{d-1}{2},\frac{1}{2}\right)\in\left(0,\frac{1}{2}\right), where Iαsubscript𝐼𝛼I_{\alpha} is the regularized incomplete beta function, we show tighter asymptotic behavior:

Theorem 5.

With error term |e|≤12​log⁡log⁡d+𝒪​(1)𝑒12𝑑𝒪1|e|\leq\frac{1}{2}\log{\log{d}}+{\cal O}(1),

b∗​(α,d)=−log⁡P​(α,d)+log⁡d+12​log⁡log⁡d+e.superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑𝑃𝛼𝑑𝑑12𝑑𝑒b^{*}(\alpha,d)=-\log{P(\alpha,d)}+\log{d}+\frac{1}{2}\log{\log{d}}+e.

4 Average-Case Analysis

Now we switch to the average-case analysis for the class ℂ​(α)ℂ𝛼\mathbb{C}(\alpha). First, we prove a lower bound for communicated bits in expectation. Then we analyze the randomized version of Sparse Dithering, which, having better theoretical guarantees than random dithering, is suboptimal in this analysis. Finally, we present a new compression operator from ℂ​(α)ℂ𝛼\mathbb{C}(\alpha), Spherical Compression, which is provably optimal.

4.1 Lower bound on average communication

In this section, we consider compression operators from ℂ​(α)ℂ𝛼\mathbb{C}(\alpha) and investigate the trade-off between normalized variance α𝛼\alpha and expected number of bits

B=sup‖x‖=1𝔼𝒞​[|E​(x)|].𝐵subscriptsupremumnorm𝑥1subscript𝔼𝒞delimited-[]𝐸𝑥B=\sup_{\|x\|=1}\mathbb{E}_{{\cal C}}\left[|E(x)|\right].

In other words, we study the trade-off for strictly α𝛼\alpha-contractive operators that encode any unit vector with no more than B𝐵B bits in expectation. In such a setting, we show the following lower bound on B𝐵B.

Theorem 6.

Let 𝒞∈ℂ​(α)𝒞ℂ𝛼{\cal C}\in\mathbb{C}(\alpha) be a compression operator such that 𝒞​(x)∈ℝd𝒞𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}(x)\in\mathbb{R}^{d} can be transferred with B𝐵B bits in expectation for any unit vector x∈𝕊d𝑥superscript𝕊𝑑x\in\mathbb{S}^{d}. Then −log⁡P​(α,d)≤B𝑃𝛼𝑑𝐵-\log P(\alpha,d)\leq B.

4.2 Randomized version of Sparse Dithering

Here we randomize Sparse Dithering to make it unbiased and estimate the number of encoding bits it needs in expectation. First we decompose the to-be-compressed vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} into the magnitude and unit direction u=x/‖x‖𝑢𝑥norm𝑥u=x/\|x\| as before. To randomize the scheme, each coordinate uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} gets rounded to one of the two nearest neighbors, so as to preserve unbiasedness; that is, if 2​ki​h≤|ui|≤2​(ki+1)​h2subscript𝑘𝑖ℎsubscript𝑢𝑖2subscript𝑘𝑖1ℎ2k_{i}h\leq|u_{i}|\leq 2(k_{i}+1)h for some ki≥0subscript𝑘𝑖0k_{i}\geq 0, then u^i=sign(ui)⁡2​k^i​hsubscript^𝑢𝑖signsubscript𝑢𝑖2subscript^𝑘𝑖ℎ\hat{u}_{i}=\operatorname*{{\rm sign}}(u_{i})2\hat{k}_{i}h where

k^i={ki with prob. ​2​(ki+1)​h−|ui|2​hki+1 with prob. ​|ui|−2​ki​h2​h.subscript^𝑘𝑖casessubscript𝑘𝑖 with prob. 2subscript𝑘𝑖1ℎsubscript𝑢𝑖2ℎsubscript𝑘𝑖1 with prob. subscript𝑢𝑖2subscript𝑘𝑖ℎ2ℎ\hat{k}_{i}=\begin{cases}k_{i}&\text{ with prob. }\ \frac{2(k_{i}+1)h-|u_{i}|}{2h}\\ k_{i}+1&\text{ with prob. }\ \frac{|u_{i}|-2k_{i}h}{2h}.\\ \end{cases}

Clearly, 𝔼​[u^]=u𝔼delimited-[]^𝑢𝑢\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{u}\right]=u and defining 𝒞​(x)=‖x‖​u^𝒞𝑥norm𝑥^𝑢{\cal C}(x)=\|x\|\hat{u}, we maintain unbiasedness 𝔼​[𝒞​(x)]=x𝔼delimited-[]𝒞𝑥𝑥\mathbb{E}\left[{\cal C}(x)\right]=x. The encoding scheme is the same as in the deterministic case. Upper bounding the expected number of bits and the variance, we obtain:

Theorem 7.

Randomized SD compression with parameter ν=ω𝜈𝜔\nu=\omega belongs to 𝕌​(ω)𝕌𝜔\mathbb{U}(\omega), communicating at most

30+log⁡d+(log⁡3+12​ω)​d30𝑑312𝜔𝑑30+\log d+\left(\log 3+\frac{1}{2\sqrt{\omega}}\right)d

bits in expectation. In particular, with ω=1/4𝜔14\omega=\nicefrac{{1}}{{4}} variance (ignoring 30+log⁡d30𝑑30+\log{d} negligible factors), it uses (1+log⁡3)​d≈2.6​d13𝑑2.6𝑑\left(1+\log 3\right)d\approx 2.6d bits in each iteration (about 121212 times less than full precision case) and forces up to 1+ω=5/41𝜔541+\omega=\nicefrac{{5}}{{4}} times more iterations, leading to ≈9.9absent9.9\approx 9.9 times bandwidth savings.

As mentioned earlier, SD is similar to random dithering with uniform levels, namely with d𝑑\sqrt{d} levels. However, with a different parametrization ν𝜈\nu and better encoding strategy, SD provides better theoretical guarantees. Indeed, random dithering with d𝑑\sqrt{d} levels communicates ≈2.8​dabsent2.8𝑑\approx 2.8d bits in expectation and requires 1+ω=21𝜔21+\omega=2 times more iterations, resulting in a factor of ≈5.7absent5.7\approx 5.7 in bandwidth saving (see Theorem 3.2 and Corollary 3.3 of [2]). For more comparisons on bandwidth savings see Table 2 in the Appendix.

4.3 New Compressor: Spherical Compression (SC)

It can be shown that randomized SD compression discussed in the previous section is suboptimal with respect to the lower bound of Theorem 6. Here we provide a simple compression operator–Spherical Compression (SC)–that achieves this lower bound with less than 333 overhead bits.

Construction and variance bound. As before, we transmit the magnitude and direction separately. For a given unit vector x∈𝕊d𝑥superscript𝕊𝑑x\in\mathbb{S}^{d}, SC generates a sequence (xt)t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑡𝑡1𝑇(x^{t})_{t=1}^{T} of i.i.d. points with ‖xt‖2=1−αsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑡21𝛼\|x^{t}\|^{2}=1-\alpha, and terminates once ‖xT−x‖2≤αsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑇𝑥2𝛼\|x^{T}-x\|^{2}\leq\alpha for some T≥1𝑇1T\geq 1. The last generated point xTsuperscript𝑥𝑇x^{T} is the compressed version of x𝑥x we need to communicate, that is 𝒞​(x)=xT𝒞𝑥superscript𝑥𝑇{\cal C}(x)=x^{T}. It follows directly from this construction that 𝒞∈ℂ​(α)𝒞ℂ𝛼{\cal C}\in\mathbb{C}(\alpha).

Encoding scheme. The crucial part of the encoding scheme is that it is enough to communicate only T𝑇T. Indeed, the communication process is the following. Importantly, the emitter and receiver have agreed on using the same random seed for generating i.i.d. points (xt)superscript𝑥𝑡(x^{t}), before the compression of any vector is performed.

Then, upon receiving the number of trials T𝑇T, the decoder can reproduce the same sequence x1,x2,…,xTsuperscript𝑥1superscript𝑥2…superscript𝑥𝑇x^{1},x^{2},\dots,x^{T} and recover xTsuperscript𝑥𝑇x^{T}. Consequently, it remains to encode the random integer T𝑇T into a binary code.

Upper bound on B𝐵B. First we show that T𝑇T follows a geometric distribution with parameter p=P​(α,d)𝑝𝑃𝛼𝑑p=P(\alpha,d). Indeed, T𝑇T can be viewed as the number of trials before the first success happens after a series of failures.

In our case, trials correspond to generating i.i.d. points xtsuperscript𝑥𝑡x^{t} and success means x∈Cd​(xt,α)𝑥superscript𝐶𝑑superscript𝑥𝑡𝛼x\in C^{d}(x^{t},\sqrt{\alpha}) which happens with probability P​(α,d)∈(0,1/2)𝑃𝛼𝑑012P(\alpha,d)\in(0,\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}). Therefore, the expected number of points xtsuperscript𝑥𝑡x^{t} we need to generate until we get into α𝛼\alpha-vicinity of the initial point x𝑥x is 𝔼​[T]=1/p=1/P​(α,d)>2𝔼delimited-[]𝑇1𝑝1𝑃𝛼𝑑2\mathbb{E}\left[T\right]=\nicefrac{{1}}{{p}}=\nicefrac{{1}}{{P(\alpha,d)}}>2. Next, we encode T𝑇T with the Golomb–Rice coding scheme, which is known to be optimal for geometric distributions. Define integer m≥0𝑚0m\geq 0 from 1/2​p≤2m<1/p12𝑝superscript2𝑚1𝑝\nicefrac{{1}}{{2p}}\leq 2^{m}<\nicefrac{{1}}{{p}} and decompose T𝑇T as T=2m​q+r𝑇superscript2𝑚𝑞𝑟T=2^{m}q+r with q≥0, 0≤r<2mformulae-sequence𝑞0 0𝑟superscript2𝑚q\geq 0,\;0\leq r<2^{m}. The quotient q𝑞q is encoded with unary coding as a string of q𝑞q zeros followed by a 1. The remainder r𝑟r is communicated with exactly m𝑚m bits using truncated binary coding. There is no need to send the value of m𝑚m as it can be computed from p𝑝p, which depends only on α𝛼\alpha and d𝑑d. Hence, the total number of bits to encode T𝑇T is no more than q+m+1𝑞𝑚1q+m+1. Note that m<log⁡1/p=−log⁡p𝑚1𝑝𝑝m<\log{\nicefrac{{1}}{{p}}}=-\log{p} is fixed, while q𝑞q depends on T𝑇T and q≤2−m​T𝑞superscript2𝑚𝑇q\leq 2^{-m}T. Hence,

B=𝔼​[q+m+1]<2−m​𝔼​[T]−log⁡p+1=12m​p−log⁡p+1≤−log⁡p+3,𝐵𝔼delimited-[]𝑞𝑚1superscript2𝑚𝔼delimited-[]𝑇𝑝11superscript2𝑚𝑝𝑝1𝑝3B=\mathbb{E}\left[q+m+1\right]<2^{-m}\mathbb{E}\left[T\right]-\log{p}+1=\frac{1}{2^{m}p}-\log{p}+1\leq-\log{p}+3,

which implies:

Theorem 8.

In the average-case analysis, Spherical Compression is optimal up to 333 extra bits; that is, it communicates B<−log⁡P​(α,d)+3𝐵𝑃𝛼𝑑3B<-\log P(\alpha,d)+3 bits in expectation.

Remark 2.

It is worth mentioning that the above compression operator satisfies ‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2≤α​‖x‖2superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2𝛼superscriptnorm𝑥2\|{\cal C}(x)-x\|^{2}\leq\alpha\|x\|^{2} in the worst case, not in expectation. Moreover, because of the symmetry of spheres and caps Cd​(xt,α)superscript𝐶𝑑superscript𝑥𝑡𝛼C^{d}(x^{t},\sqrt{\alpha}), it can be seen from the construction that 𝔼​[𝒞​(x)]𝔼delimited-[]𝒞𝑥\mathbb{E}\left[{\cal C}(x)\right] points to the same direction as the initial vector x𝑥x. Thus, with an appropriate (fixed) scaling factor, it can be made unbiased as well.

5 Experiments

5.1 Setting

We consider both l2−limit-fromsubscript𝑙2l_{2}-regularized logistic regression and ridge regression. In both cases, we use regularizing coefficient λ=1n𝜆1𝑛\lambda=\frac{1}{n}. We run this on multiple datasets, and show that our compression methods provide significant savings in communication (measured in bytes). The algorithm we used is Compressed Gradient Descent, which consists in iterating

xt+1=xt−1L​𝒞​(∇f​(xt)),superscript𝑥𝑡1superscript𝑥𝑡1𝐿𝒞∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑡x^{t+1}=x^{t}-\frac{1}{L}{\cal C}\left(\nabla{f(x^{t})}\right),

where f𝑓f is the loss function, L𝐿L is the smoothness constant of f𝑓f computed explicitly. We stop the process whenever ‖xt−x⋆‖2‖x0−x⋆‖2≤10−4superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑡superscript𝑥⋆2superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥0superscript𝑥⋆2superscript104\frac{\|x^{t}-x^{\star}\|^{2}}{\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\|^{2}}\leq 10^{-4}, where x⋆superscript𝑥⋆x^{\star} is the minimizer of f𝑓f and is computed beforehand for all problems.

5.2 Communication versus Convergence

In this experiment, we look at convergence, measured as ‖xt−x⋆‖2‖x0−x⋆‖2superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑡superscript𝑥⋆2superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥0superscript𝑥⋆2\frac{\|x^{t}-x^{\star}\|^{2}}{\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\|^{2}} with respect to the number of bits communicated, for various compression operators. As shown in Figure 1, our compression operators significantly outperform all other operators. It is important that we compare our methods with the benchmark ‘Basic’, which sends a 32-bits float for every element in the gradient, sending a total of 32​d32𝑑32d bits at every iteration. In addition, we run these experiments with Top-k𝑘k for all 1≤k≤d1𝑘𝑑1\leq k\leq d and pick the best representative in the comparison, naming it ‘Best Top−k𝑘-k’.

5.3 Total Communication as a Function of α𝛼\alpha

Here, we let α=1−k/d𝛼1𝑘𝑑\alpha=1-\nicefrac{{k}}{{d}} vary and in Figure 2 we show the total number of bits communicated before converging to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accuracy, with ϵ=10−4italic-ϵsuperscript104\epsilon=10^{-4}. This clearly shows the superiority of our methods. It is important to note that Sparse Dithering can beat the optimal Spherical Compression, because it is unbiased, so it requires significantly less iterations. It’s important to note that for 1≤k≤d1𝑘𝑑1\leq k\leq d, we plot Top-k𝑘k at α=1−k/d𝛼1𝑘𝑑\alpha=1-\nicefrac{{k}}{{d}}.

Appendix

Appendix A Discussion on Finite Precision Floats

In the paper, we formally consider compression of arbitrary vectors of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}, but in practice, in computers, real numbers are represented with finite-precision floats, typically using 32 bits. As a consequence, a nonzero real cannot be too small, too large, and its precision is limited. Compression, like every operation, amounts to a sequence of elementary arithmetic operations, each being exact only up to so-called ‘machine precision’, which is difficult to model. Thus, we could restrict ourselves to vectors in {0}∪{x:r≤‖x‖≤R}0conditional-set𝑥𝑟norm𝑥𝑅\{0\}\cup\{x:r\leq\|x\|\leq R\} for some 0<r<R0𝑟𝑅0<r<R, instead of the whole space ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}, but this would not account for the finite precision of floats, and since this set is not stable by arithmetic operations, this would not be enough to model the setting in all rigor. So, we prefer to stick with the general setting of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} throughout the paper, since there is no issue with limit cases of very large or very small nonzero numbers, that would deserve a particular discussion; the finite precision makes them automatically irrelevant in practice. In other words, the finite representation of reals is not more problematic with compression than for any learning or optimization task, and more generally for the numerical implementation of any mathematical algorithm.

In particular, considering floats with 32 bits, a non-compressed vector x𝑥x of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} is actually represented using 32​d32𝑑32d bits. When we decompose x𝑥x into its ‘gain’ ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\| and ‘shape’ x/‖x‖∈𝕊d𝑥norm𝑥superscript𝕊𝑑x/\|x\|\in\mathbb{S}^{d}, there is no trickery in considering that ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\| is represented using 31 bits (the sign bit can be omitted) and that x/‖x‖𝑥norm𝑥x/\|x\| is actually compressed. The multiplication by ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\| at decompression has finite precision, just like any arithmetic operation.

Appendix B Proofs for Section 2

B.1 Relaxed classes of compression operators

As mentioned in the paper and in Appendix A, any operator from 𝕌​(ω),𝔹​(α),ℂ​(α)𝕌𝜔𝔹𝛼ℂ𝛼\mathbb{U}(\omega),\,\mathbb{B}(\alpha),\,\mathbb{C}(\alpha) cannot be encoded with a finite number of bits. For example, in the case of 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha), the inequality (4) breaks near x=0𝑥0x=0 and ‖x‖→∞→norm𝑥\|x\|\rightarrow\infty. However, in practice, machine floats have finite precision and we do not deal with nonzero values that are too small and too large. To reflect this practical aspect into the theory, we adjust the definition of α𝛼\alpha-contractive compressors 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) and consider the following class instead. For the sake of concreteness, we carry out the discussion for the class 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) only and note that analogous observations can be adopted for other two classes.

Definition 5 (Practical α𝛼\alpha-contractive compressions).

Let α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1) and R≥1𝑅1R\geq 1 be fixed. We denote by 𝔹1​(α,R)superscript𝔹1𝛼𝑅\mathbb{B}^{1}(\alpha,R) the class of (possibly randomized) operators 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} such that

𝔼​[‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2]≤α​‖x‖2,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2𝛼superscriptnorm𝑥2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}\right]\leq\alpha\|x\|^{2},\quad if1/R≤‖x‖≤Rif1𝑅norm𝑥𝑅\displaystyle\text{if}\quad\nicefrac{{1}}{{R}}\leq\|x\|\leq R
𝒞​(x)=0,𝒞𝑥0\displaystyle{\cal C}(x)=0,\quad if‖x‖<1/R​ or ​‖x‖>R.ifnorm𝑥1𝑅 or norm𝑥𝑅\displaystyle\text{if}\quad\|x\|<\nicefrac{{1}}{{R}}\;\text{ or }\;\|x\|>R.

Note that, for simplicity, we take r=1/R𝑟1𝑅r=\nicefrac{{1}}{{R}}.

The class of all α𝛼\alpha-contractive operators 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) can be seen as the limit of the class 𝔹1​(α,R)→𝔹​(α)→superscript𝔹1𝛼𝑅𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}^{1}(\alpha,R)\to\mathbb{B}(\alpha) as R→∞→𝑅R\to\infty. The advantage of the class 𝔹1​(α,R)superscript𝔹1𝛼𝑅\mathbb{B}^{1}(\alpha,R) compared to 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) is that it allows an encoding with finite number of bits. Next, we relax the definition of 𝔹1​(α,R)superscript𝔹1𝛼𝑅\mathbb{B}^{1}(\alpha,R) as follows:

Definition 6 (Weak α𝛼\alpha-contractive compressions).

Let α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1) and R>0𝑅0R>0 be fixed. We denote by 𝔹2​(α,R)superscript𝔹2𝛼𝑅\mathbb{B}^{2}(\alpha,R) the class of (possibly randomized) operators 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} such that

𝔼​[‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2]≤α​R2,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2𝛼superscript𝑅2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}\right]\leq\alpha R^{2},\quad if‖x‖≤Rifnorm𝑥𝑅\displaystyle\text{if}\quad\|x\|\leq R
𝒞​(x)=0,𝒞𝑥0\displaystyle{\cal C}(x)=0,\quad if‖x‖>R.ifnorm𝑥𝑅\displaystyle\text{if}\quad\|x\|>R.

The following simple lemma shows that the latter class is much more general and contains the first class.

Lemma 1.

If R≥α−1/4𝑅superscript𝛼14R\geq\alpha^{-\nicefrac{{1}}{{4}}} then 𝔹1​(α,R)⊂𝔹2​(α,R)superscript𝔹1𝛼𝑅superscript𝔹2𝛼𝑅\mathbb{B}^{1}(\alpha,R)\subset\mathbb{B}^{2}(\alpha,R).

Proof.

Let 𝒞∈𝔹1​(α,R)𝒞superscript𝔹1𝛼𝑅{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}^{1}(\alpha,R) with α​R4≥1𝛼superscript𝑅41\alpha R^{4}\geq 1. If ‖x‖<1/Rnorm𝑥1𝑅\|x\|<\nicefrac{{1}}{{R}} then

𝔼​[‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2]=‖x‖2<1R2≤α​R2.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2superscriptnorm𝑥21superscript𝑅2𝛼superscript𝑅2\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}\right]=\|x\|^{2}<\frac{1}{R^{2}}\leq\alpha R^{2}.

If 1/R≤‖x‖≤R1𝑅norm𝑥𝑅\nicefrac{{1}}{{R}}\leq\|x\|\leq R then

𝔼​[‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2]≤α​‖x‖2≤α​R2.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2𝛼superscriptnorm𝑥2𝛼superscript𝑅2\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}\right]\leq\alpha\|x\|^{2}\leq\alpha R^{2}.

∎

Now, the lower bound α​ 4b/d≥1𝛼superscript4𝑏𝑑1\alpha\,4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1 was proved for any 𝒞∈𝔹2​(α,R)𝒞superscript𝔹2𝛼𝑅{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}^{2}(\alpha,R) and hence for any 𝒞∈𝔹1​(α,R)𝒞superscript𝔹1𝛼𝑅{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}^{1}(\alpha,R) with sufficiently large R𝑅R. Since this lower bound is independent of R𝑅R, it can be associated with the limit class 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) under the described practical caveat.

Lastly, we define another class of contractive compression operators which will be used to provide some examples related to the optimality.

B.2 Two senses of optimality for compression: Proof of Proposition 1

If 𝒞∈𝔹​(α)𝒞𝔹𝛼{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha) with α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1), then to minimize L𝐿L-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex function f𝑓f, CGD needs 𝒪​(11−α​κ​log⁡1ϵ)𝒪11𝛼𝜅1italic-ϵ{\cal O}\left(\frac{1}{1-\alpha}\kappa\log\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right) steps for ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-accuracy, where κ=Lμ𝜅𝐿𝜇\kappa=\frac{L}{\mu} is the condition number of f𝑓f (see e.g. Theorem 13 of [6]). If we choose to not use compression operator and send uncompressed gradients (α=0𝛼0\alpha=0) then we get iteration complexity of GD 𝒪​(κ​log⁡1ϵ)𝒪𝜅1italic-ϵ{\cal O}\left(\kappa\log\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right), which is 11−α11𝛼\frac{1}{1-\alpha} times smaller than for CGD. If compression operator is unbiased with variance α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0, then the iteration complexity becomes 𝒪​((1+α)​κ​log⁡1ϵ)𝒪1𝛼𝜅1italic-ϵ{\cal O}\left((1+\alpha)\kappa\log\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right) (see e.g. [18]). Alternatively, for an unbiased compression operator 𝒞∈𝕌​(α)𝒞𝕌𝛼{\cal C}\in\mathbb{U}(\alpha) one has 11+α​𝒞∈𝔹​(α1+α)11𝛼𝒞𝔹𝛼1𝛼\frac{1}{1+\alpha}{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}\left(\frac{\alpha}{1+\alpha}\right), which implies the iteration complexity 𝒪​(11−α1+α​κ​log⁡1ϵ)=𝒪​((1+α)​κ​log⁡1ϵ)𝒪11𝛼1𝛼𝜅1italic-ϵ𝒪1𝛼𝜅1italic-ϵ{\cal O}\left(\frac{1}{1-\frac{\alpha}{1+\alpha}}\kappa\log\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right)={\cal O}\left((1+\alpha)\kappa\log\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right).

B.3 Dimension-tolerant compression schemes: Proof of Theorem 1

Statement (i) directly follows from (1) and Lemma 3, since b≥d​log4⁡1α𝑏𝑑subscript41𝛼b\geq d\,\log_{4}\frac{1}{\alpha} in the biased case and b≥d​log4⁡ωω+1𝑏𝑑subscript4𝜔𝜔1b\geq d\,\log_{4}\frac{\omega}{\omega+1} in the unbiased case.

Statement (ii): first we construct an unbiased compression operator on the unit sphere, which together with ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\| factor will prove the unbiased case. It follows from [19] (see also [26], Section 3) that one can construct an unbiased compression operator 𝒞:𝕊d→ℝd:𝒞→superscript𝕊𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{S}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} with ω=𝒪​(dlog⁡m/d)𝜔𝒪𝑑𝑚𝑑\omega={\cal O}\left(\frac{d}{\log\nicefrac{{m}}{{d}}}\right) variance and log⁡m𝑚\log m bits where the dependence of m𝑚m from d𝑑d can be up to exponential. Choosing m=2c​d−31𝑚superscript2𝑐𝑑31m=2^{cd-31}, we obtain a number of c​d𝑐𝑑cd bits to encode 𝒞​(x/‖x‖)𝒞𝑥norm𝑥{\cal C}(x/\|x\|) together with ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\| and variance

ω=𝒪​(dlog⁡m−log⁡d)=𝒪​(dc​d−log⁡d−31)=𝒪​(1/c).𝜔𝒪𝑑𝑚𝑑𝒪𝑑𝑐𝑑𝑑31𝒪1𝑐\omega={\cal O}\left(\frac{d}{\log m-\log d}\right)={\cal O}\left(\frac{d}{cd-\log d-31}\right)={\cal O}(\nicefrac{{1}}{{c}}).

For the biased case, Lemma 3 implies that the operator 1ω+1​𝒞1𝜔1𝒞\frac{1}{\omega+1}{\cal C} has variance

α=1−1ω+1=1−1𝒪​(1/c)+1=11+Ω​(c)𝛼11𝜔111𝒪1𝑐111Ω𝑐\alpha=1-\frac{1}{\omega+1}=1-\frac{1}{{\cal O}(\nicefrac{{1}}{{c}})+1}=\frac{1}{1+\Omega(c)}

and uses the same number c​d𝑐𝑑cd of bits as 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}.

C.1 Asymptotic tightness of the lower bound (1): Proof of Theorem 2

First of all, note that to construct a α𝛼\alpha-contractive compression operator 𝒞:𝕊d→ℝd:𝒞→superscript𝕊𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{S}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} on the unit sphere, it is sufficient to cover the unit sphere 𝕊dsuperscript𝕊𝑑\mathbb{S}^{d} by spherical caps generated from balls of radius α𝛼\sqrt{\alpha}. C.2 Deterministic-biased version of SD: Proof of Theorem 3

Compression operator and variance bound. To compress a given nonzero vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we first compress the normalized vector u=x/‖x‖∈𝕊d𝑢𝑥norm𝑥superscript𝕊𝑑u=x/\|x\|\in\mathbb{S}^{d} and then rescale it. To quantize the coordinates of unit vector u𝑢u, we apply dithering with levels 2​ki​h,ki≥02subscript𝑘𝑖ℎsubscript𝑘𝑖02k_{i}h,\;k_{i}\geq 0, where h=ν/dℎ𝜈𝑑h=\sqrt{\nicefrac{{\nu}}{{d}}} is the half-step and ν≥0𝜈0\nu\geq 0 is a free parameter of the compression operator. For each ui,i∈[d]subscript𝑢𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑑u_{i},i\in[d] we choose the nearest level so that ||ui|−2​ki​h|≤hsubscript𝑢𝑖2subscript𝑘𝑖ℎℎ||u_{i}|-2k_{i}h|\leq h. Letting u^i=sign(ui)⁡ 2​ki​hsubscript^𝑢𝑖signsubscript𝑢𝑖2subscript𝑘𝑖ℎ\hat{u}_{i}=\operatorname*{{\rm sign}}(u_{i})\,2k_{i}h we have |ui−u^i|≤hsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript^𝑢𝑖ℎ|u_{i}-\hat{u}_{i}|\leq h for all i∈[d]𝑖delimited-[]𝑑i\in[d]. Therefore

‖u−u^‖2=∑i=1d(ui−u^i)2≤d​h2=ν.superscriptnorm𝑢^𝑢2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript^𝑢𝑖2𝑑superscriptℎ2𝜈\|u-\hat{u}\|^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{d}(u_{i}-\hat{u}_{i})^{2}\leq dh^{2}=\nu.

Note that, after rescaling with ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\|, this gives a compression with variance at most ν𝜈\nu. However, ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\| is not always the best option. Specifically, we can choose the scaling factor γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 so as to minimize the variance ‖x−γ​u^‖2superscriptnorm𝑥𝛾^𝑢2\|x-\gamma\hat{u}\|^{2}, which yields the optimal factor γ∗=⟨x,u^⟩‖u^‖2superscript𝛾𝑥^𝑢superscriptnorm^𝑢2\gamma^{*}=\frac{\left\langle x,\hat{u}\right\rangle}{\|\hat{u}\|^{2}} with optimal variance ‖x−γ∗​u^‖2=sin2⁡φ​‖x‖2superscriptnorm𝑥superscript𝛾^𝑢2superscript2𝜑superscriptnorm𝑥2\|x-\gamma^{*}\hat{u}\|^{2}=\sin^{2}\varphi\,\|x\|^{2}, where φ∈[0,π/2]𝜑0𝜋2\varphi\in[0,\nicefrac{{\pi}}{{2}}] is the angle between x𝑥x and u^^𝑢\hat{u}. Hence, defining the compression operator as 𝒞​(x)=γ∗​u^𝒞𝑥superscript𝛾^𝑢{\cal C}(x)=\gamma^{*}\hat{u}, we have the following bound on the variance:

‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2≤min⁡(ν,sin2⁡φ)​‖x‖2,superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2𝜈superscript2𝜑superscriptnorm𝑥2\|{\cal C}(x)-x\|^{2}\leq\min\left(\nu,\sin^{2}\varphi\right)\|x\|^{2},

where φ∈[0,π/2]𝜑0𝜋2\varphi\in[0,\nicefrac{{\pi}}{{2}}] is the angle between x𝑥x and 𝒞​(x)𝒞𝑥{\cal C}(x), and in the case 𝒞​(x)=0𝒞𝑥0{\cal C}(x)=0, we let φ=π/2𝜑𝜋2\varphi=\nicefrac{{\pi}}{{2}}.

Encoding. Now, we describe the encoding scheme itself; that is, how many and which bits we need to communicate for γ∗​u^superscript𝛾^𝑢\gamma^{*}\hat{u}. We introduce the following notations:

C.3 Tighter bounds on minimal communication: Proofs of Theorems 4 and 5

The first motivation for this is that even though the uncetainty principle (1) is strong for constant α𝛼\alpha, it is not tight when α𝛼\alpha goes to 1 as d𝑑d goes to infinity. In particular, for α=d−1d𝛼𝑑1𝑑\alpha=\frac{d-1}{d}, it says that the number of bits is at least d​log⁡(1−1/d)/2𝑑11𝑑2d\log(1-1/d)/2, which is constant. However, we can show that when α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, one needs at least log⁡(d)𝑑\log(d) bits. This explains why there is no way to only communicate a fixed number of bits per round while still having α<1𝛼1\alpha<1. Moreover, we will compute an explicit estimate of b∗​(α,d)superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑b^{*}(\alpha,d), as a function of d𝑑d and α𝛼\alpha only, with a very low error of 12​log⁡log⁡d+C12𝑑𝐶\frac{1}{2}\log{\log{d}}+C for some absolute constant C𝐶C.

Proof of Theorem 4.

Proving the result is equivalent to proving that the surface of the unit sphere cannot be covered by less than d𝑑d smaller, identical balls. We can prove this easily by induction. To make the induction step, let us assume, without loss of generality, that one of the smaller balls is centered on the positive x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} axis. Since the radius of this smaller ball is less than 1, the unit (d−1)𝑑1(d-1)-dimensional sphere with x1=0subscript𝑥10x_{1}=0 is disjoint from the first smaller ball, which means, by induction, that it will itself require at least d−1𝑑1d-1 additional smaller balls, leading to the desired result. ∎

In fact, the previous result can be used to obtain the following result.

Definition 8.

For a covering of the surface of the unit sphere using identical spherical caps, we define the density of the cover to be the average number of caps covering a point on the surface of the unit sphere. Identically, this is equal to the number of spherical caps used multiplied by the fraction of the unit sphere covered by a single spherical cap.

Theorem 10.

There exists an absolute constant B𝐵B such that if the surface of the unit sphere is covered with identical smaller spherical caps, then the density of the covering is at least B​d𝐵𝑑Bd.

Proof.

We split this into two cases. The first case is when the radius of the spherical cap is larger than 1−1d11𝑑\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{d}}. In this case, each spherical cover will cover at least a fraction of A​(d)=Prob​(x1≥1d)𝐴𝑑Probsubscript𝑥11𝑑A(d)={\rm Prob}\left(x_{1}\geq\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}}\right) where x𝑥x is chosen uniformly from the surface of the unit sphere. One can easily show that there exists C1>0subscript𝐶10C_{1}>0 such that A​(d)>C1𝐴𝑑subscript𝐶1A(d)>C_{1} for all d. Indeed, it is enough to see that A​(d)>0𝐴𝑑0A(d)>0 for all d𝑑d and that A​(d)𝐴𝑑A(d) approaches 1−ϕ​(1)1italic-ϕ11-\phi(1) where ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is the CDF of a standard normal. Combining this bound with the previous result of requiring at least d𝑑d caps to cover the surface of the unit sphere, the density is at least C1​dsubscript𝐶1𝑑C_{1}d when the radius of the spherical cap is at least 1−1d11𝑑\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{d}}.
In the second case, when the radius of the spherical cap is less than 1−1d<1−1d+111𝑑11𝑑1\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{d}}<\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{d+1}}, The Coxeter–Few–Rogers “simplex” bound shows [11] that the density is at least C2​dsubscript𝐶2𝑑C_{2}d for some absolute constant C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}. Choosing B=min⁡(C1,C2)𝐵subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2B=\min\left(C_{1},C_{2}\right) gives us the desired result. ∎

Theorem 11 (see [11]).

There exists an absolute constant A𝐴A such that for any d𝑑d and any spherical radius r<1𝑟1r<1, there exists a cover for the surface of the unit sphere with smaller, identical spherical caps of radius r𝑟r such that the density of the covering is at most A​d​log⁡d𝐴𝑑𝑑Ad\log{d}.

Lemma 4.

If ‖x‖=1norm𝑥1\|x\|=1 and ‖v−x‖2≤αsuperscriptnorm𝑣𝑥2𝛼\|v-x\|^{2}\leq\alpha for some t𝑡t, then for v′=1−α​v‖v‖superscript𝑣′1𝛼𝑣norm𝑣v^{\prime}=\frac{\sqrt{1-\alpha}v}{\|v\|}, one has ‖x−v′‖2≤αsuperscriptnorm𝑥superscript𝑣′2𝛼\|x-v^{\prime}\|^{2}\leq\alpha. In other words, if some balls of radius α𝛼\sqrt{\alpha} cover the surface of the unit sphere, then projecting them onto the sphere of radius 1−α1𝛼\sqrt{1-\alpha} will still cover entirely the surface of the unit sphere.

Proof.

The initial condition is equivalent to 1−α+‖v‖2≤2​⟨v,x⟩1𝛼superscriptnorm𝑣22𝑣𝑥1-\alpha+\|v\|^{2}\leq 2\langle v,x\rangle which, using AM-GM, implies that 2​1−α​‖v‖≤2​⟨v,x⟩21𝛼norm𝑣2𝑣𝑥2\sqrt{1-\alpha}\|v\|\leq 2\langle v,x\rangle, which can be rearranged to to look like 1−α+‖v′‖2≤2​⟨v′,x⟩1𝛼superscriptnormsuperscript𝑣′22superscript𝑣′𝑥1-\alpha+\|v^{\prime}\|^{2}\leq 2\langle v^{\prime},x\rangle or ‖v′−x‖2≤αsuperscriptnormsuperscript𝑣′𝑥2𝛼\|v^{\prime}-x\|^{2}\leq\alpha, as desired. ∎

The above discussion leads us to our next result on b∗​(α,d)superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑b^{*}(\alpha,d), which is an important quantity to study. First, it tells us that operators 𝒞∈𝔹​(α)𝒞𝔹𝛼{\cal C}\in\mathbb{B}(\alpha) cannot compressed with less than b∗superscript𝑏b^{*} bits. Moreover, it tells us that this bound is tight, because there is at least one operator in 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) that can be compressed to no more than b∗​(α,d)superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑b^{*}(\alpha,d) bits. Thus, we proceed with estimating b∗​(α,d)superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑b^{*}(\alpha,d) explicitly with a very small estimation error of 12​log⁡log⁡d+𝒪​(1)12𝑑𝒪1\frac{1}{2}\log{\log{d}}+{\cal O}(1).

Proof of Theorem 5.

Recall that P​(α,d)=12​Iα​(d−12,12)𝑃𝛼𝑑12subscript𝐼𝛼𝑑1212P(\alpha,d)=\frac{1}{2}I_{\alpha}(\frac{d-1}{2},\frac{1}{2}) is also equal to the fraction of the surface area of the surface of the unit sphere with 1−α≤x11𝛼subscript𝑥1\sqrt{1-\alpha}\leq x_{1}. This can be viewed as the probability that a point x𝑥x chosen uniformly on the unit sphere satisfies 1−α≤x1𝛼𝑥\sqrt{1-\alpha}\leq x. In order to prove the theorem, we will prove the upper and lower bounds on b∗​(α,d)superscript𝑏𝛼𝑑b^{*}(\alpha,d) separately.

We first prove the lower bound. Let 𝒞𝒞{\cal C} be an arbitrary operator in 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) that can be encoded with no more than b𝑏b bits. This means that at most 2bsuperscript2𝑏2^{b} possible values can be communicated. Let c1,…,cVsubscript𝑐1…subscript𝑐𝑉c_{1},\dots,c_{V} be all the possible decodings, with V≤2b𝑉superscript2𝑏V\leq 2^{b}. Now, if we consider the balls B​(ci,α)𝐵subscript𝑐𝑖𝛼B(c_{i},\sqrt{\alpha}), the surface of the unit sphere must be covered. Indeed, if ‖x‖=1norm𝑥1\|x\|=1 and x𝑥x is not covered, then all the possible encodings of 𝒞​(x)𝒞𝑥{\cal C}(x) will produce a point whose distance from x𝑥x is more than α𝛼\sqrt{\alpha}, which contradicts the fact that the operator is in 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha).

Now, since these small balls cover the surface of the unit sphere, one can use Lemma 4 to show that the balls centered at B​(Ci,α)𝐵subscript𝐶𝑖𝛼B(C_{i},\sqrt{\alpha}), where Ci=1−α​ci‖ci‖subscript𝐶𝑖1𝛼subscript𝑐𝑖normsubscript𝑐𝑖C_{i}=\frac{\sqrt{1-\alpha}c_{i}}{\|c_{i}\|}, should also be a covering. Using Theorem 10, we know that the density of this new coverage is at least B​d𝐵𝑑Bd, while it is at most F​2b𝐹superscript2𝑏F2^{b}, where F𝐹F is the fraction of the surface area of the unit sphere that each one of these balls cover. In fact, one can compute F𝐹F explicitly as P​(α,d)𝑃𝛼𝑑P(\alpha,d) = Prob​(x1≥1−α)Probsubscript𝑥11𝛼{\rm Prob}\left(x_{1}\geq\sqrt{1-\alpha}\right) where x𝑥x is chosen uniformly on the surface of the unit sphere. This gives us the lower bound b≥−log⁡P​(α,d)+log⁡d+log⁡B𝑏𝑃𝛼𝑑𝑑𝐵b\geq-\log{P(\alpha,d)}+\log{d}+\log{B}.

For the upper bound, one can use a constant number of bits to communicate ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\|, then one can use the covering from Theorem 11 with radius equal to α𝛼\sqrt{\alpha} and quantize x𝑥x to the nearest spherical cap center, which is guarantee to be within a distance of α𝛼\sqrt{\alpha}, ensuring that this quantization is in 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha). Now, since this covering has density no more than A​d​log⁡d𝐴𝑑𝑑Ad\log{d}, and since its density is equal to V​P​(α,d)𝑉𝑃𝛼𝑑VP(\alpha,d), where v𝑣v is the number of spherical caps used and P𝑃P is, as defined above, the fraction of the surface area covered by one a spherical cap of radius α𝛼\sqrt{\alpha}, one can conclude that v≤A​d​log⁡dP​(α,d)𝑣𝐴𝑑𝑑𝑃𝛼𝑑v\leq\frac{Ad\log{d}}{P(\alpha,d)}, which means that the centers can be encoded using no more than −log⁡P​(α,d)​log⁡d+log⁡log⁡d+log⁡A𝑃𝛼𝑑𝑑𝑑𝐴-\log{P(\alpha,d)}\log{d}+\log{\log{d}}+\log{A} bits, yielding the desired upper bound.∎

Appendix D Proofs for Section 4

D.1 Lower bound on average communication: Proof of Theorem 6

Let X𝑋X be a random vector with uniform distribution over the unit sphere 𝕊dsuperscript𝕊𝑑\mathbb{S}^{d} and X^=𝒞​(X)^𝑋𝒞𝑋\hat{X}={\cal C}(X) be the compressed (random) vector. Note that, X^^𝑋\hat{X} has two source of randomness, one from the random vector X𝑋X and the other coming from the compression operator 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}. Based on the assumption of finiteness of B𝐵B (otherwise the lower bound is trivial), we conclude that 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}, and hence the random vector X^^𝑋\hat{X}, are discrete; that is, the set of possible values they can take is finite or countably infinite. Note that X^^𝑋\hat{X} can be encoded with B𝐵B bits in expectation with respect to its own source of randomness, as

B=sup‖x‖=1𝔼𝒞​[|E​(x)|]≥𝔼𝒞,X​[|E​(X)|]=𝔼X^​[|E​(X)|].𝐵subscriptsupremumnorm𝑥1subscript𝔼𝒞delimited-[]𝐸𝑥subscript𝔼𝒞𝑋delimited-[]𝐸𝑋subscript𝔼^𝑋delimited-[]𝐸𝑋B=\sup_{\|x\|=1}\mathbb{E}_{{\cal C}}\left[|E(x)|\right]\geq\mathbb{E}_{{\cal C},X}\left[|E(X)|\right]=\mathbb{E}_{\hat{X}}\left[|E(X)|\right].

Thus, the discrete random source X^^𝑋\hat{X} admits an encoding with expected binary description length of B𝐵B. Applying Shanon’s source coding theorem on lossless compression666see e.g. Theorem 5.5.1+Corollary or Theorem 5.11.1 of [9], we get B≥H​(X^)𝐵𝐻^𝑋B\geq H(\hat{X}), where H𝐻H indicates the entropy of the source777A discrete random vector can be mapped to a discrete random variable preserving the same probability distribution (and so we can extend the source-coding inequality), as entropy is defined through probability mass/density function, not the actual values of the random source. in bits.

Next, using the mutual information and relative entropy of X^^𝑋\hat{X} and X𝑋X, we further lower bound it as follows:

B≥H​(X^)≥H​(X^)−H​(X^|X)=I​(X^,X)=H​(X)−H​(X|X^).𝐵𝐻^𝑋𝐻^𝑋𝐻conditional^𝑋𝑋𝐼^𝑋𝑋𝐻𝑋𝐻conditional𝑋^𝑋B\geq H(\hat{X})\geq H(\hat{X})-H(\hat{X}|X)=I(\hat{X},X)=H(X)-H(X|\hat{X}).

Now, we denote by A𝐴A the surface area of the unit sphere 𝕊dsuperscript𝕊𝑑\mathbb{S}^{d}. For a given point v∈ℝd𝑣superscriptℝ𝑑v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, let A′​(v)superscript𝐴′𝑣A^{\prime}(v) be the surface area of the cap Cd​(v,α)=Bd​(v,α)∩𝕊dsuperscript𝐶𝑑𝑣𝛼superscript𝐵𝑑𝑣𝛼superscript𝕊𝑑C^{d}(v,\sqrt{\alpha})=B^{d}(v,\sqrt{\alpha})\cap\mathbb{S}^{d}. Using Lemma 4, it can be shown that in order to maximize the surface area of Cd​(v,α)superscript𝐶𝑑𝑣𝛼C^{d}(v,\sqrt{\alpha}), the center v𝑣v should be on the sphere of radius 1−α1𝛼\sqrt{1-\alpha}, namely ‖v‖2=1−αsubscriptnorm𝑣21𝛼\|v\|_{2}=\sqrt{1-\alpha}. Using the formula888see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_cap#Hyperspherical_cap for the surface area of spherical caps, we compute the normalized surface area of Cd​(v,α)superscript𝐶𝑑𝑣𝛼C^{d}(v,\sqrt{\alpha}) to be P​(α,d)=12​Iα​(d−12,12)𝑃𝛼𝑑12subscript𝐼𝛼𝑑1212P(\alpha,d)=\frac{1}{2}I_{\alpha}(\frac{d-1}{2},\frac{1}{2}). Thus, at best Cd​(v,α)superscript𝐶𝑑𝑣𝛼C^{d}(v,\sqrt{\alpha}) covers the portion P​(α,d)𝑃𝛼𝑑P(\alpha,d) of the unit sphere 𝕊dsuperscript𝕊𝑑\mathbb{S}^{d}, where Iαsubscript𝐼𝛼I_{\alpha} is the regularized incomplete beta function. Therefore, for an arbitrary v∈ℝd𝑣superscriptℝ𝑑v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, one has the upper bound A′​(v)≤P​(α,d)​Asuperscript𝐴′𝑣𝑃𝛼𝑑𝐴A^{\prime}(v)\leq P(\alpha,d)A. Note that as Iαsubscript𝐼𝛼I_{\alpha} is upper bounded by 111 (which directly follows from the definition) we get P​(α,d)<1/2𝑃𝛼𝑑12P(\alpha,d)<\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}.

Since X𝑋X is uniform on the unit sphere, its probability density function is 1/A1𝐴\nicefrac{{1}}{{A}} and so the entropy H​(X)=log⁡(A)𝐻𝑋𝐴H(X)=\log(A). Similarly, since the random vector X𝑋X conditioned with X^=v^𝑋𝑣\hat{X}=v is uniform over Cd​(v,α)superscript𝐶𝑑𝑣𝛼C^{d}(v,\sqrt{\alpha}), we have H​(X|X^=v)=log⁡A′​(v)𝐻conditional𝑋^𝑋𝑣superscript𝐴′𝑣H(X|\hat{X}=v)=\log A^{\prime}(v). Hence

H​(X|X^)=𝔼X^​[H​(X|Y=X^)]=𝔼X^​[log⁡A′​(X^)]≤log⁡(P​(α,d)​A),𝐻conditional𝑋^𝑋subscript𝔼^𝑋delimited-[]𝐻conditional𝑋𝑌^𝑋subscript𝔼^𝑋delimited-[]superscript𝐴′^𝑋𝑃𝛼𝑑𝐴H(X|\hat{X})=\mathbb{E}_{\hat{X}}\left[H(X|Y=\hat{X})\right]=\mathbb{E}_{\hat{X}}\left[\log A^{\prime}(\hat{X})\right]\leq\log\left(P(\alpha,d)A\right),

resulting in the desired lower bound

B≥H​(X)−H​(X|X^)≥log⁡(A)−log⁡(P​(α,d)​A)=−log⁡P​(α,d).𝐵𝐻𝑋𝐻conditional𝑋^𝑋𝐴𝑃𝛼𝑑𝐴𝑃𝛼𝑑B\geq H(X)-H(X|\hat{X})\geq\log(A)-\log\left(P(\alpha,d)A\right)=-\log P(\alpha,d).

D.2 Randomized-unbiased version of Sparse Dithering: Proof of Theorem 7

In this section, we randomize Sparse Dithering to make it unbiased.

Compression operator and variance bound. Again, to compress a given nonzero vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we decompose x𝑥x into the scalar ‖x‖norm𝑥\|x\| and the unit vector u=x/‖x‖𝑢𝑥norm𝑥u=x/\|x\|. in expectation, where n^0≔#​{i∈[d]:k^i=0}≔subscript^𝑛0#conditional-set𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscript^𝑘𝑖0\hat{n}_{0}\coloneqq\#\{i\in[d]\colon\hat{k}_{i}=0\}.

The parameter ν=1/4𝜈14\nu=\nicefrac{{1}}{{4}} is approximately the maximizer for

which shows the gain in total communication complexity.
